title: ASX tumbles as US factory activity hits GFC lows
text:
The weak result sparked selling on Wall Street overnight, sending the Dow Jones down 1.3 per cent to 26573.04, while the S &P 500 fell 1.2 per cent to 2940.25, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 1.1 per cent to 7908.68.

"We've known the manufacturing sector has been weak for many months and it's the consumers that are holding the US out of a recession, so this doesn't really change the outlook too much," Mr Curtayne said.

"The market is just wondering how long the consumers can hang in there."

Those fears spread through global markets, pushing the FTSE 100 down 0.7 per cent and the Euro Stoxx 50 down 1.4 per cent on Tuesday.

The major banks more than reversed their late rally fuelled by Tuesday's monetary easing, leading the market losses during Wednesday's trade.

NAB was the worst of the four majors, sliding 2.3 per cent to end the session at $29.02 after announcing it had put aside an extra $832 million after tax to refund customers of its scandal-ridden financial advice arm.

The bank also said it would take a $348 million hit to its second-half earnings after changing how it accounted for software expenses.

Commonwealth Bank dropped 2.1 per cent to $79.60, Westpac slid 1.7 per cent to $29.21 and ANZ declined 1.5 per cent to $28.05.

All four major banks said they would pass on part of the RBA's rate cut, however none passed on the cut in full to its principal and interest customers.

The major miners also weakened across the board on Wednesday, amid concerns that a global manufacturing slowdown would weigh on demand for metals.

BHP dropped 1.9 per cent to $36.30, Rio Tinto closed 1.6 per cent lower at $91.09, Fortescue Metals Group declined 0.3 per cent to $8.72, and South32 fell 3.8 per cent to $2.55.

Ansell shares dropped 3.9 per cent to $26.63, with concerns over global manufacturing weighing on its share price.

UBS noted the contraction in global and eurozone PMIs were likely to hurt the latex glove manufacturer, referring to purchasing managers' indexes.

"Historically it has been difficult for Ansell to generate organic growth when these two key indicators are in decline," said analyst Tom Godfrey,

Just 19 stocks traded higher on Wednesday, with only one gold miner advancing through the session.

Northern Star Resources was the only precious metal producer closing in the green, as it firmed 2.5 per cent to $11.29.

Demand for bonds was also slightly stronger on Wednesday, pushing the yield on the Australian 10-year note down 1 basis point to 0.963 per cent.

Bond proxy real estate investment trust and infrastructure stocks were slightly firmer as a result.

Lendlease firmed 0.7 per cent to $17.68, Vicinity Centres advanced 1.2 per cent to $2.60 and Charter Hall added 0.5 per cent to $4.34.

Mayne Pharma also weathered the broad market sell-off, climbing 18.9 per cent to 63¢ after signing a 20-year exclusive supply and license agreement with Mithra Pharmaceuticals to commercialise E4/DRSP, a combined oral contraceptive, in the United States. The approval and launch of the product is expected in the first half of 2021.
description: Australian shares tumbled on Wednesday as the weakest US factory activity in a decade sparked fears a global recession might be imminent.
